FULL TITLE : AN ACT PROVIDING A SOCIALIZED MICROFINANCING PROGRAM FOR MICRO ENTERPRISES THEREBY PROMOTING ENTREPRENEURSHIP

ACTIONS TAKEN BY THE COMMITTEE
COMMITEE HEARINGS/ACTIONS:
      1. Deliberated upon by the Mother Committee on 2017-05-09
          -Committee Chairman Peter Unabia stated that House Bill No. 5158 or the Pondo sa Pagbabago at Pag-asenso Bill (P3 bill) aims to replace the 5-6 money lending scheme and to make available a micro lending facility with an interest rate lower than the prevailing market rate. If enacted into law, it will ensure the continuity of the P3 Program being implemented by the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) through the Small Business Corporation (SB Corp.). In his sponsorship remarks, Rep. Gil Acosta cited the difficulty of the MSMEs to access the credit programs for MSMEs due to high interest rate, and voluminous and stringent requirements, which is why they resort to borrowing from the “5-6” micro lending scheme. Mr. Melvin Abanto, Senior Vice President of the SB Corp., informed the Committee that the P3 Program was rolled out in three pilot areas, namely, Mindoro, Sarangani and Tacloban. The Committee requested the DTI to submit a status report on the roll-out in the three pilot provinces, and the guidelines for the P3 Program. Dir. Jerry Clavesillas of the Bureau of Micro, Small, Medium Enterprise Development (BMSMED) of the DTI stated that other countries have a budget allocation for microfinancing. He emphasized that through the P3 Act, micro lending will be institutionalized and it will be mandatory for the government to lend out to the micro enterprise sector. Ms. Pia Bernandette Roman-Tayag of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) informed the body that microfinancing has long been promoted by the BSP and that 168 banks are engaged therein. The representatives from the DTI, BSP, Rural Bankers Association of the Philippines (RBAP), Chamber of Thrift Bank (CTB) and Microfinance Council of the Philippines, Inc. (MCPI) expressed their support for the passage of the measure. Among the other comments and suggestions given by the resource persons are: (a) need to strengthen the guarantee facility because of the risk of lending to micro enterprises; and (b) perception that loans to micro enterprises are dole-outs, accounting for the low repayment rate. Rep. Angelina Tan suggested that the P3 loans be given to the poorest populations, instead of the poorest provinces. The Committee agreed to convene a technical working group, to be chaired by Rep. Tan, to fine-tune the provisions of the bill.
          -There being no objection, said Section 4 now reads as follows: “Section 4. Establishment of Entrepreneurial Training Programs. – All government offices and agencies shall prepare and implement a post-service Government Service Entrepreneurship Development Program (GSEDP) for their employees based on guidelines prescribed by the Civil Service Commission (CSC). The GSEDP shall be designed in such a manner as to help employees learn what they need to know to develop ideas and actualize them into successful businesses and how to increase entrepreneurial opportunities in their respective municipalities, provinces and regions. The GSEDP shall introduce employees to technology transfer systems, entrepreneurial educational programs, entrepreneurial networks, financial literacy and livelihood trainings/seminars, as part of the agency’s annual training plan. “Intensive preparation activities and learning modules for retirees shall start five (5) years prior to their retirement date. The post-service assistance may be given on a consultancy basis to strengthen the proposed programs to be implemented under this Act. “Each agency shall have full-time, in-house business tutors and counsellors on the implementation of the proposed programs for retiring employees. The regular funding for the program shall be taken from the agency’s annual budget.” In Section 5, Rep. Noel opted to delete the last portion of Section 5 regarding the preferential rights of government employees’ cooperatives to operate revenue-generating activities in available government-owned sites and facilities, said Section 5 to now read, as follows: “Section 5. Establishment of Cooperatives and Savings and Loan Associations. – All government agencies shall promote and support the establishment of cooperatives with the assistance of the Cooperative Development Authority (CDA) and of savings and loans associations, by recognizing, protecting and upholding the rights of employees to organize cooperatives and savings and loan associations in their respective offices to generate financial resources and develop employees’ entrepreneurial skills. Existing cooperatives and savings and loans associations in government agencies shall incorporate the development of employees’ entrepreneurial skills as part of their objective. Cooperatives and savings and loan associations shall be encouraged to retain the membership of employees even after retirement from public service.” After deliberating on Section 6, the TWG agreed to add a proviso therein, to now read as follows: “SEC. 6. Networking with Government Financial Institutions. - The heads of all government agencies, including government-owned and controlled corporations concerned, shall coordinate with existing government financial institutions (GFIs) to provide sources of financing for the viable income-generating entrepreneurial projects of their retired employees, subject to the mandate of the GFI concerned. Experts from the GFIs shall be called upon to conduct lectures, workshops in capacity building for entrepreneurship skills and live case studies of successful entrepreneurs. Participants shall be taught to identify and evaluate opportunities for new ventures and to understand how the capital investment process works. All GFIs shall set aside funds for this purpose: Provided, That financing of the entrepreneurial projects of retired government employees shall be dependent on the strength and quality of the proposed enterprise’s project and business cash flows, overall credit worthiness and other mitigating measures, in accordance with safe and sound banking practices, where applicable.” The TWG likewise agreed to adopt the recommendation of LBP on Section 7 for the CSC to spearhead the coordination among government agencies for the preparation, implementation and monitoring of a comprehensive plan for the government employees entrepreneurial development, as well as its funding sources, instead of creating a Council as provided for in the bill. Furthermore, Rep. Noel enjoined each agency to prepare and submit to the CSC a comprehensive plan to develop entrepreneurial capabilities, managerial expertise and technical skills and also to monitor the implementation of the program. The CSC was requested to submit the agency’s confirmation on the afore-stated role of the CSC the following week. Inputs were also made by the TWG in Sections 7, 8 and 9, which now read, to wit: “SEC. 7. Monitoring of the Government Employees’Entrepreneurship Development Program. – The Civil Service Commission (CSC) shall spearhead the coordination among all agencies and the four public sector unions in the preparation, implementation and monitoring of a comprehensive plan for the government employees’ entrepreneurial development, including funding sources. “Each agency shall be tasked to prepare and submit to the CSC a comprehensive plan to develop entrepreneurial capabilities, managerial expertise, financial planning and technical skills, and fund sources. “SEC. 8. Post-service Assistance. – All government agencies shall extend post-service assistance to their respective retirees and shall include this as part of their human resources development plan. They shall develop a post-service assistance program to backstop aspiring entrepreneurs in the development and implementation of their ideas. The program shall cover the entire gamut of the venture creation process from idea generation to building viable business, with emphasis on the nurturing roles of the GFIs, and highlighting successful entrepreneurs as models. The assistance shall include follow-up programs after the business has been set-up, in order to ensure the profitability and sustainability of the business. “SEC. 9. Implementing Rules and Regulations. – The CSC shall promulgate the rules and regulations needed to implement the provisions of this Act within sixty (60) days after it effectivity.” The Secretariat was directed to prepare and finalize the substitute bill reflecting the amendments agreed upon, and the committee report thereon, for the consideration and approval of the Mother Committee.
      2. Deliberated by the TWG on 2017-05-18
          -The TWG agreed on the following amendments: 1. On Section 2 (Declaration of Policy): Insert the phrase “and programs” after the word “plans”. 2. On Section 3 (Objectives): a) In paragraph (a), the Secretariat was directed to find another term for “hassle-free”. Change “poorest provinces” to “poorest populations” where the P3 Program will be made available, as suggested by Rep. Tan; b) In paragraph (b), change the word “replace” with the phrase “provide a better alternative to” in referring to informal lenders. 3. On Section 6 (Features of the P3 Fund): Instead of specifying the loanable amount and minimal interest rate, the TWG proposed that “The loanable amount for individual loans, and the interest rate to the conduits and to the end beneficiaries shall be set and regularly reviewed by the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise Development (MSMED) Council: Provided,That the interest rate shall be lower than the prevailing interest rate charged by the micro finance institutions (MFIs)”, and that “The interest earnings shall accrue to the P3 Fund”. 4. On Section 7 (Policy Oversight Function): Clarified that the MSMED Council shall perform “policy” oversight functions on the P3 Fund; and that the MSMED Council shall “submit to the President and to Congress, through the Congressional Oversight Committee on Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise Development (COC-MSMED), a yearly report on the status of the P3 Fund”. SB Corp. was requested to craft the revised language for the Appropriations Section and submit the same to the Secretariat. The Secretariat was directed to prepare and e-mail the draft substitute bill reflecting the amendments based on the discussions and agreements arrived at by the TWG. The TWG participants were requested to review the same and submit their comments thereon the following week.
      3. Recommendations submitted by the TWG on 2017-05-29
          -Rep. Tan, Chairperson of the technical working group (TWG), underscored the importance of the enactment of House Bill No. 5158, introduced by Reps. Peter “Sr. Pedro” M. Unabia, Jocelyn S. Limkaichong, Rodrigo A. Abellanosa, Gil “Kabarangay” P. Acosta, Alexandria P. Gonzales, Marisol C. Panotes, Carlito S. Marquez, Salvador B. Belaro, Jr. and Bernadette Herrera-Dy, entitled: “An Act Providing a Socialized Microfinancing Program for Micro Enterprises Thereby Promoting Entrepreneurship”, which is to institutionalize the P3 Program which the DTI started to implement this year through the SB Corp. She stated that it aims to replace the 5-6 money lending scheme and make available a micro lending facility with an interest rate lower than the prevailing market rate. Rep. Tan reported that the TWG, which met on May 18, 2017 to fine-tune the provisions of the P3 Bill, was participated in by Rep. Acosta. It took into consideration the comments and recommendations of the concerned agencies in attendance, namely, Department of Trade and Industry-Bureau of Micro Small and Medium Enterprise Development (DTI-BMSMED), Small Business Corporation (SB Corp.), and Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), as well as the submitted position papers of the other stakeholders, namely, the Rural Bankers Association of the Philippines (RBAP), Chamber of Thrift Banks (CTB), and the Microfinance Council of the Philippines (MFCP) who were not able to attend the TWG meeting. Rep. Tan discussed the insertions, deletions and amendments on HB 5158, based on the discussions and agreements arrived at by the TWG. It also reflected the inputs submitted by the DTI and SB Corp. to the Committee Secretariat after the meeting. Among the amendments are as follows: 1. On Section 2 (Declaration of Policy): Inserted the words “policies” and “programs” in addition to “plans” which the State will develop for MSMEs; 2. On Section 3 (Objectives): a) In paragraph (a), changed “poorest provinces” to “poorest populations” where the P3 Program will be made available; b) In paragraph (b), changed the word “replace” with the phrase “provide a better alternative to” in referring to informal lenders; 3. On Section 5 (Lead Implementing Agency): a) Added a new mode of fund delivery to micro enterprises, to wit: “Provision of guarantees to loans granted by the banks to qualified P3 beneficiaries”, aside from direct lending and wholesale lending to conduits which shall on-lend to micro enterprises; b) Changed the percentage of total loans disbursed from “twenty percent (20%)” to “ten percent (10%)” which shall be provided to SB Corp. to support its administrative and operating expenses; and added a statement that the said amount will “be sourced from the earnings of the P3 Fund.”; 4. On Section 6 (Features of the P3 Fund): a) Instead of specifying the loanable amount and minimal interest rate, the substitute bill states that “The loanable amount for individual loans, and the interest rate to the conduits and to the end beneficiaries shall be set and regularly reviewed by the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise Development (MSMED) Council: Provided, That the interest rate shall be lower than the prevailing interest rate charged by the micro finance institutions (MFIs).” It further states that “The interest earnings shall accrue to the P3 Fund”. b) States that “There shall be no collateral requirement from the P3 loan beneficiaries” but deleted the phrase that the P3 fund shall be guarantee-free; 5. On Section 7 (Policy Oversight Function): Clarified that the MSMED Council shall perform “policy” oversight functions on the P3 Fund; and that the SMED Council shall “submit to the President and to Congress, through the Congressional Oversight Committee on Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise Development (COC-MSMED), a yearly report on the status of the P3 Fund”; and 6. On Section 8 (Appropriations): The SB Corp. proposed the following language, in lieu of the language in the original bill, to read as follows: “The amount of P4.3 billion shall be appropriated for the initial year of implementation of this Act, broken down as follows: a. P3 billion loan fund; b. P1 billion guarantee fund; and c. P300 million mobilization and capacity building fund for SB Corp. Thereafter, the amount of P3 billion in loan fund and P1 billion in guarantee fund shall be allocated to the P3 Fund for the next three (3) years: Provided, That at least half of the funds allocated in the past year shall have been disbursed: Provided, further, That the guarantee fund already released to the P3 Fund shall be leveraged not more than three times and may also be lent pending calls on its guarantee. In addition, an amount equivalent to the loan provisioning and guarantee calls in the past year shall be allocated annually to the P3 Fund.”
      4. Deliberated by the TWG on 2018-01-23
          -Rep. Villafuerte presented his and Rep. Victor Yap’s proposed amendments to Section 2 (Declaration of Policies), Section 8 (Inclusive Innovation), Section 10 (Functions of the NIC), Section 11 (Secretariat to the Council), Section 12 (MSME Innovation) and Section 19 (Advocacy and Community Education). He also discussed additional provisions on an innovation development credit and financing system, and credit quota. He requested for the approval of the proposed amendments and additional provisions. TWG Chair Laogan stated the need to get the comments of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) on the credit quota. The representatives from the Department of Science and Technology (DOST), Intellectual Property Office (IPO), Commission on Audit (COA), Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), Department of Education (DepEd), Department of Budget and Management (DBM), Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE), Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT), Asian Institute of Management (AIM) Policy Center, and Abad, Alcantara & Associates gave their general comments on the said measures. On the perceived duplication of functions of the proposed National Innovation Council (NIC) with the existing MSMED Council, Committee Chairman Peter Unabia concurred with the author that the NIC needs to focus on innovation for the country to prosper. As to the proposed Innovation Fund, the DBM suggested to source it from the contingent fund of the President, instead of from government savings. The Departments which have not yet submitted their official position papers were directed to submit the same on or before the 29th of January 2018. TWG Chair Laogan stated that the TWG participants will be informed of the schedule of the next meeting, during which the TWG will discuss the proposed substitute bill section by section.
      5. Scheduled for meeting/hearing on 2018-02-27

          -Substitute Bill to House Bill Numbered 5158 was approved with amendment.
